newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan/US may intervene if dlr above 110 yen -Utsumi.
newsitem.headline: Japan/US may intervene if dlr above 110 yen -Utsumi.

text.p: Financial authorities in the U.S. and Japan could step in or intervene verbally if the yen appreciates beyond 110 yen, a former senior official of Japan's Ministry of Finance (MOF) said in an interview with a Japanese economic daily.

"If the yen advances past 110 yen to the dollar, Japanese and U.S. authorities are likely to send a signal to the market," Makoto Utsumi, former MOF vice minister of international affairs, was quoted as saying in Friday's edition of the Nihon Keizai shimbun.
Utsumi, currently a professor of Japan's Keio University, was also quoted as saying that there is no discrepancy in the foreign exchange policies of the United States and Japan.
"The U.S. authorities' stance is clear that they will not use foreign exchange as a trade policy tool," Utsumi added.
Judging from Japan's economic conditions and interest rates, the yen is not likely to appreciate sharply, Utsumi told the newspaper.
